channel.title: Baosen Zhang
channel.description: Baosen Zhang is an Assistant Professor in the Electrical Engineering Department at the University of Washington.

item.title: Paper in ACM E-Energy: Exploiting Vulnerabilities of Load Forecasting Through Adversarial Attacks
item.description:
To appear as a paper in ACM E-Energy. We study how an adversary might attack forecasting techniques in power systems and analyze the potential impact on system operations, such as load shedding and increased dispatch costs. These types attack shows that forecasting techniques can be vulnerable to cyber security threats even when the adversary has no information about the system under attack and very little information about the forecasting algorithms themselves (compared to standard data injection attacks which require full knowledge of the system topology). Code

  1. Y. Chen, Y. Tan, and B. Zhang, “Exploiting Vulnerabilities of Load Forecasting Through Adversarial Attacks,” in ACM E-Energy, 2019.
    • BibTeX
      • @inproceedings{Chen19,

  title = {Exploiting Vulnerabilities of Load Forecasting Through Adversarial Attacks},
  year = {2019},
  booktitle = {ACM E-Energy},
  link = {https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.06606},
  blog = {2019-4-15-security}
}

item.title: Paper in ICLR: designing convex neural networks for control
item.description:
To appear as a paper in ICLR. We design a class of neural networks to be input-convex, which achieves excellent learning plus control performances on tasks such as Mujoco locomotion and building energy management.

  1. Y. Chen, Y. Shi, and B. Zhang, “Optimal Control Via Neural Networks: A Convex Approach,” in International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2019.
    • BibTeX
      • @inproceedings{Chen18convex,
  author = {Chen, Y. and Shi, Y. and Zhang, B.},
  title = {Optimal Control Via Neural Networks: A Convex Approach},
  year = {2019},
  booktitle = {International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR)},
  blog = {2019-1-10-convex_nn},
  link = {https://openreview.net/forum?id=H1MW72AcK7}
}

item.title: Outreach at the Seattle Science Center
item.description: Thanks to Chase, Ling, Tinu, Tanner and Victor for putting on a booth at the Seattle Science Center! We had demos of our research (joint with Lilian Ratliff), as well as props illustrating max-flow/min-cut and the Monty Hall problem. Surprising, kids got the Monty Hall faster than the adults!

item.title: Optimal Battery Control Under Cycle Aging Mechanisms
item.description: Paper on using batteries in regulation markets under realistic degradation

item.title: Real-Time Prediction of the Duration of Distribution System Outages using NLP
item.description: Using NLP for Distribution System Outages Duration Prediction, code available here.

item.title: Pan and Yuanyuan Selected to the Rising Stars Workshop
item.description: Congratulations to Pan and Yuanyuan for being selected to participate in the 2018 Rising Stars in EECS workshop at MIT. The UW EE article is at http://www.ee.washington.edu/spotlight/two-electrical-engineers-selected-to-attend-prestigious-conference-for-women/
